image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: (Father of Jon Llewellyn Kyl), a Representative from Iowa; born in Wisner, Cumming, County, Nebr., May 9, 1919; graduated from Wayne Prep High School, Wayne, Nebr., 1937; graduated from Nebraska State Teachers College, Wayne, Nebr., 1940; graduated from the University of Nebraska, 1947; teacher; faculty, Nebraska State Teachers College, Wayne, Nebr., 1940-1950; television journalist; unsuccessful candidate for election to the Eighty-sixth Congress in 1958; elected as a Republican to the Eighty-sixth Congress, by special election to fill the vacancy caused by the death of United States Representative Steven V. Carter, and reelected to the two succeeding Congresses (December 15, 1959-January 3, 1965); unsuccessful candidate for reelection to the Eighty-ninth Congress in 1964; elected as a Republican to the Ninetieth and to the two succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1967-January 3, 1973); unsuccessful candidate for reelection to the Ninety-third Congress in 1972; assistant secretary, congressional and legislative affairs, Department of the Interior, 1973-1977; business executive; died on December 23, 2002, in Phoenix, Ariz.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Ralph Nader Congress Project. Citizens Look at Congress: John H. Kyl, Republican Representative from Iowa. Washington, D. C.: Grossman Publishers, 1972.

researchRecord.name: 1970, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Henry Kyl to Paul Engle written on June 29, 1970. In the letter, John Kyl accepts an invitation from Paul Engle.

researchRecord.name: In the Karl M. LeCompte Papers, 1939-1972, 10.5 linear feet.
In the Wiley Mayne Papers, 1966-1974, 118 linear feet.
In the Fred Schwengel Papers, ca. 1940-1993, 327 linear feet.
1972, 7 commercials on 4 videoreels.
researchRecord.description: The commercials were used during John Kyl's 1972 campaign for the U.S. Congress in District 4 of Iowa, Democratic Party.

recordLocation.name: The Julian P. Kanter Political Commercial Archive, Department of Communication
